Posted By: Cyberium (1/23/2013 11:11:23 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
It's the kind of card I have a hard time imagining a time I wouldn't like to see it in my hand.  
  
The first ability is just nice. I feel a bit greedy in thinking I would have preferred it to be 4 damage to target creature rather than player, but for 2 mana for 4 damage I don't think I have any right to complain.  
  
The second effect is so versatile and useful, it makes it a charm that I can breathe a little easier when I have it in my hand, since I know that whatever my plans are, I won't have to see them foiled by any common removal. Its counter-wrath use is definitely great, and I have a sense it was practically a necessity considering that the Boros ability encourages you to over-extend yourself.  
  
The third ability is there, it's a combat trick, and it's the least exciting, but it's still going to win games. I was never overly impressed with [Double Cleave](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Double Cleave), but since it comes as an additional option on an already great card (and also can be used on other people's cr... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: Redgurr (1/22/2013 6:04:17 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Indeed, by far the best charm of the cycle, for only 2 mana, you get such versitality between 3 good effects. The first, 4 damage direct, means great pressure on your opponent, making him caring for evrey damage he's about to get. Imagine what deck with 4 of these can do..  
The 2nd effect pretty much reads : 'No, [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) kills just your creatures, thanks for the effort.'  
And the last effect can be used as a finishing blow, or as an really nice combat trick.  
Boros is really strong this set, probably they're never gonna be as strong again.

Posted By: BloodCrank (1/29/2013 12:27:26 AM)

posts.post_content:
After having played both with and against this card extensively over pre-release weekend, I can safely say:  
  
What the hell, Wizards. Was this not playtested? This card is one of the single most broken cards in the history of magic. IN WHAT IS ABOUT TO BE STANDARD, I've been turn *3* killed because of this card at least 4 times in the 6 games I played against my friend's new white/red/blue deck.  
  
I don't understand how they print a card as an uncommon that should be a rare at minimum. It still would have been the best charm of the block if it only did 3 damage to target player and only granted first strike.
posts.html:
After having played both with and against this card extensively over pre-release weekend, I can safely say:

What the hell, Wizards. Was this not playtested? This card is one of the single most broken cards in the history of magic. IN WHAT IS ABOUT TO BE STANDARD, I've been turn 3 killed because of this card at least 4 times in the 6 games I played against my friend's new white/red/blue deck.

I don't understand how they print a card as an uncommon that should be a rare at minimum. It still would have been the best charm of the block if it only did 3 damage to target player and only granted first strike.
